timeline.message:
Add MongoDBExtension for JUnit 5

Introduce MongoDBTestService and MongoDBContainer to remove MongoDB
service specific code from the JUnit 4 MongoDBInstance rule.

Add a JUnit 5 extension for MongoDB that is using the new
MongoDBTestService.

The MongoDBInstance API has been kept to avoid changing tons of tests.
It can go once we moved all test over to JUnit 5.

Closes #7655

timeline.bodyText: I think it would make sense to hide the details of retrieving a collection in a method MongoDBTestService#getCollection(String name).
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: This constructor is unused. I think we can get rid of it.
timeline.author: alex-konn

replies.bodyText: This is used by the JUnit 5 extension framework when using @ExtendWith. I suppressed the warning and added a comment.
replies.author: bernd

replies.bodyText: Ah! OK, that's fine as well.
replies.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: I would suggest to rename this method to createWithDefaultVersion. That would clearly communicate what it's doing (and make the Javadoc for the method redundant as well IMO).
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: The throws Exception clause can be removed.
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: The throws Exception clause can be removed.
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: The throws Exception clause can be removed (if the one on MongoDBTestService#close is removed as well).
timeline.author: alex-konn
alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: I would find the test easier to understand, if we explicitly assert that there is no collection at all using something like assertThat(mongodb.mongoConnection().getMongoDatabase().listCollections()).isEmpty();
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: I would simply omit such generic Javadoc comments. The one on the class is really helpful. This one is just noise for me, because it provides no information that is not immediately visible from the method signature.
timeline.author: alex-konn
alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: I think it makes sense to give all tests meaningful names. I would call this one importsCollectionFromFixture or something similar.
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText:
I think the test could be improved by moving the tests asserting that the same instance id is used to a nested class. Running tests in order is only relevant for them so @TestMethodOrder would only be needed on the nested class and we could also get rid of the Order annotation on the last two tests.
The static field for instanceIds would still have to go in the outer class, which is a bit ugly, but a trade off, I'd be fine with.
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't it be enough to already assert here that the injected instance's id is equal to the one injected in the test before?
timeline.author: alex-konn

timeline.bodyText: From my point of view, we can also get rid of the unused createForEachTest method.
timeline.author: alex-konn
alex-konn

timeline.message:
Revert "Remove unused constructor in MongoDBExtension"

This reverts commit 6ff957b486bebfab257d0dd1d63c99d8ee5b0b31.
Add note that no-args constructor is needed by the JUnit 5 extension
Clear up assertions where we expect no collections at all

Refactor MongoDBExtension#processFixtures

Extract some private methods to make the method more readable.

Co-authored-by: Alex Konn <alexander@graylog.com>
Merge branch 'mongodb-junit-extension' of github.com:Graylog2/graylog2-server into mongodb-junit-extension
Move same instance check into nested test class
